text:
S-X2
1962. Aikenhead, M. Amanda (Mrs. James Robert)
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name ____________________________
Present Address ____________________________
Pioneer Address ____________________________
Year you came to Saskatchewan ____________

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: Mrs. (A.R.) Aikenhead. (Amanda)

Present Address: ____________________________

Pioneer Address: ____________________________

Year you came to Saskatchewan: ______

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan.)

PLEASE NOTE:

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914 and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that only one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 8

   How many of these were bachelor's homes? 1

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? once a month

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? yes after church

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? most visiting without formal invitation

   What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? afternoon

   What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? yes

   How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Take pot luck there was always plenty.

   If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? when family was young, we all went

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? yes

   Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

   To put up a homestead shack of logs, or stables there was no roundup in our part of Sask. men came to work & the women fed them

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe. Some had parties but we did not attend. A young man asked me to go to a dance, I said, "I don't dance." He said, "I'll teach you." I did not go. I knew my parents in cut would not like it.

   Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. yes but we did not keep in touch with them.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?
NEIGHBOURLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many houses were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 8

How many of these were bachelor's homes? 1

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Once a month

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Yes after church

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Visit without formal invitation

What time of the day did you go? - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Afternoon

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "call polack" used, or was some other expression common?) We just said "there was always plenty."

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had arrived in? Refreshments

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to look after the place? Whole family was young, we all went

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the bees were for, and how often they occurred.

You had a homestead shack of logs, or stables

You were our property until our party of four

Men came to work & the women fed them

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, what sort of drives or dances in homes? Describe, some had parties, but not

did not attend. A young man asked me to go to a dance, I said, "I don't dance," he said, "I'll teach you"

I did not go. I knew my parents would not let it

Were those more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks once a month, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

School was used until the Town Hall was built then all activities there.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of? How large was it?
Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? Town of Kelfort after 1903.

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? Village

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.)?

Town Hall was used for most gatherings.

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Card parties were not allowed by Methodists. We played Blind man's buff, Crocinole, Kiss the Queen, Join the shop society.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, florists, etc., if you have not described these on the school questionnaire.) Give dates.

9. When was your first community hall built? How large was it? What material was it made of? Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? To what extent did it serve the place of homes or the school house as a place for social entertainments? For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the school house for district gatherings, until came to the hall in town for other entertainments, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? How were babies and small children provided for? How were horsecars sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Was there card playing for a prize? What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Card parties were not allowed by Methodists. We played blind man's buff, croquet. Miss the dance, join the church society.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? 

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Yes.

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable. We all noticed quite a change in social life when we got the telephone installed about 1906-1907 (think Mrs Jameson has got this information)

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Yes.

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization. June 1914 Sugar was $28. hundred & when $9 got first shipment it dropped to $22. J.R. Aikenhead was organizer + manager.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it? 50%.

How many women belonged? How often did it meet? Once a month.

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization? Farmers especially wanted a lower cost of living. There was no social function.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? No.

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
12. What activities did you participate in? (e.g., sports, clubs, religious organizations)

13. Were there any other activities or events in your community?

14. Describe any other details of visiting parties, etc.

15. What was the name of the first organization established in your community?

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' Association in your community?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your community?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one religious group (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money? **Canvas**

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? **Some built Small Halls!**

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.?  
Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? **No** Give dates if possible.  
Who provided the lantern and the slides? **The man who ran the show**

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?  
**Ball**

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?  
**Skipping. Steal the wedge.**
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, who started it, its purpose, who belonged (men, women, young people), whether it included colored people only or was racially mixed, whether it was located within a school district, or was interested in the welfare of the entire community, or was connected with the church, so they need not be included here.

That means were commonly used by organizations for raising money:

Camera-Club

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

Home Built-Small

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

Ball.

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

Skipping. Steal the wedge.
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games? 

Checkers, Crokinole, Dominoes

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

If the older folks had time they played but with chores to do + home work there was not much time

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible. July 7, 1901 Community Picnic

26. Who organized it? It is in a diary Stoney Creek's annual Picnic

There was no picnic, P.O. was Melfort but Stoney Creek dist.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? In May 25, 1896, Carroll River (now Kinistino) + Stoney Creek now Melfort celebrated the Queen's birthday by playing Base Ball.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? No, the Queen's Birthday was celebrated here at Walter Mansele May 24, 1894

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? Ball game, mens, womens + childrens races

Indian races Indians took their trousers off + ran barelegged.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? Everyone come + bring a basket, Ontario style + all eat together

31. What did you have to eat and drink? Tea + Coffee were provided

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? As soon as crowds could get together after dinner
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Feet," "Lace," "Whistling" or others, checkers or other games? 

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? 

Explain. 

If the older folks had time they played card with 

whom to do + home work that was not much time 

Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind 

of work? 

Explain. 

23. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrow- 
heads, gophers or other objects or animals or games in the snow? Describe. 

24. 

PROMPTS AND STORIES. 

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? 

Give year and month if possible. 

26. Who organized it? 

It is in a diary entry made by annual Picnic 

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school 

district, Sunday school, club, organization, etc.? 

In May 1896, Carroll River (now Kinsella) + County Fair 

Now held at Olds, Ed. The Games Birthday 

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? 

Over the Games Birthday 

and all held here at first one that has been held 

If not, do you know the date of the first one that has been held? 

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, 
etc.)? Ball games, women + children races 

Indian new Indians took their horses off + paraded 

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did 
families and friends form smaller groups? 

Only one came + having a buffet, Ontario style 

+ all eat together. Tea + coffee were provided 

31. What did you have to eat and drink? 

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? 

At noon as crowds could get together after dinner
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

The Indians from Ft. La Corne about 25 miles N.W. of the Chagosses' Kinatino reservation about 20 miles S.E. of Millar always came to the picnic at corner. The sick & well, old & young came in wagons. Big Jim brought his wife who was dying of TB. They pitched a tent & she lay on the ground in the tent. In the early afternoon she died.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

Mrs. Craig & I went into the tent & wrapped her in a sheet & then Big Jim took her away in his wagon for burial at the Chagosses' reserve.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

In the early years, everybody went and there was only one or two in a year. Although the men had Base Ball games. Today every organization has a picnic even the different rooms in school have them.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams? The diary says Base Ball teams played.

What year? In 1894. How long did it continue? Could not tell.

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.). About 1905. Hockey & Curling.

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for? 1906-1908, skating & Curling. Curling rink built later just over.
35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give data when changes became noticeable.

In the early years, every family went and there was only one or two in a year, although the main had been Ball Games, today every organization has a picnic even though different groups in school have them.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (many women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

My diary says Baseball team played

What year? About 1894. How long did it continue? Could not tell.

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for. 1906-1908.

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for? 1906-1908.

Skating + curling.

Curling rink built later just over
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community?
   Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?
   Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st).

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

Garley Kennell was in a Hockey team in U.S.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

My father brought about 40 Sunday School library books & donated them to the Sunday School.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?
   What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

not that I can remember

48. Was there a school library? No When was it begun?
   To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?
40. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading?

41. Was there a school library? When was it begun?

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

42. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school?

43. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

44. Did you buy many books after you closed your library? Give details.

45. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

46. What kind of books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible; if not, list as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.)

47. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?

48. What kind of books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible; if not, list as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.)
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? Yes, downtown.

When was it started? Who started it?

Is it still in existence? We now have a regional library.

If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

Mrs. W. Clift was librarian for a long time. Mrs. Laidlaw was another librarian.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

Melfort Moon was first published in Melfort in Sept. 23, 1903 + we subscribed for it + took it till it closed up, Sept. 24, 1947.

Carrot River Journal was published Oct. 2, 1908 + we also subscribed for it. The Country Guide, different church papers. We have taken Star Phoenix for a number of years.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

I have in my possession the 1st copy of the Carrot River Journal, The Moon + the last copy of the Melfort Moon.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

The Bible.

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.

There was not much time to read as in the early days, making a home, raising a family of 8, gardening + chores. There was not much time left to read except the Bible.
52. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? If so, when was it started?

53. Is it still in existence? If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

54. Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it had, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, etc.

55. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west? Did you have any particular preferences? How much did they cost?

56. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

57. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

58. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain. You were not much in a hurry to read as in the early days, making a home, raising a family of 8 children, and working hard over very much time. You had enough the Bible.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? An Organ

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? Some had Violins

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

Since going to my own home we got a Williams piano. It is now at my daughter's home.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

When the family were growing up we spent some time singing.

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home? We used Hymns

in the community?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? Yes When was it started? 1905. Who started it? How long did it continue? We haven't heard yet. How many were in it? Who was bandmaster? Joe Taylor. What instruments were included? Nearly all that a full band requires.

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.

Members had nice uniforms & played at most every gathering that it was invited to. All had good instruments of their own.
9.

Musical Instruments:
56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?
57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

When the family was growing up, we had a William Henry time singing in the community. (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home? We used Hymns.

In the community:

61. Was "folly music" or music of the country you came from popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? Yes

Who started it?

How many were in it?

What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where,

If members had uniforms, what events the band played for.

Members had over uniforms played at most every gathering that was invited to all good instrument of their own.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

Hobbies and Special Interests.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

General

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
10.

64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the national press? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. In what ways has your community changed since the early days? What is the reason for this change?

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections," such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Explain.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned.

(use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary)
Oxford.

No. 613 S

If Slimtrim Fasteners are to be included, please specify.

Spécifiez si vous voulez des agrafes Slimtrim.

Mississauga, Ontario L5T 1W8
Oxford
No. 613 S
